sentences.text: Human action recognition from well-segmented 3D skeleton data has been intensively studied and attracting an increasing attention .
Online action detection goes one step further and is more challenging , which identifies the action type and localizes the action positions on the fly from the untrimmed stream .
In this paper , we study the problem of online action detection from the streaming skeleton data .
We propose a multi-task end-to-end Joint Classification-Regression Recurrent Neural Network to better explore the action type and temporal localiza-tion information .
By employing a joint classification and regression optimization objective , this network is capable of automatically localizing the start and end points of actions more accurately .

Specifically , by leveraging the merits of the deep Long Short-Term Memory -LRB- LSTM -RRB- subnetwork , the proposed model automatically captures the complex long-range temporal dynamics , which naturally avoids the typical sliding window design and thus ensures high computational efficiency .
Furthermore , the subtask of regression optimization provides the ability to forecast the action prior to its occurrence .
To evaluate our proposed model , we build a large streaming video dataset with annotations .
Experimental results on our dataset and the public G3D dataset both demonstrate very promising performance of our scheme .

Online action detection goes one step further and is more challenging , which identifies the action type and localizes the action positions on the fly from the untrimmed stream . In this paper , we study the problem of online action detection from the streaming skeleton data . By employing a joint classification and regression optimization objective , this network is capable of automatically localizing the start and end points of actions more accurately . Specifically , by leveraging the merits of the deep Long Short-Term Memory -LRB- LSTM -RRB- subnetwork , the proposed model automatically captures the complex long-range temporal dynamics , which naturally avoids the typical sliding window design and thus ensures high computational efficiency . To evaluate our proposed model , we build a large streaming video dataset with annotations . Experimental results on our dataset and the public G3D dataset both demonstrate very promising performance of our scheme .
kg2text: This paper proposes a novel approach to online human action detection from streaming skeleton data. The proposed model, which combines joint classification-regression optimization, automatically localizes and forecasts actions more accurately than previous methods. This network has been designed to capture complex long-range temporal dynamics, allowing it to efficiently process temporal data. Our dataset demonstrates the effectiveness of this approach on both our own annotations and publicly available datasets like G3D. The study of human action recognition from well-segmented 3D skeleton data goes one step further in understanding human actions.

The 'streaming skeleton data' and 'a large streaming video dataset with annotations' are both types of datasets. The 'Online action detection' problem involves identifying actions in real-time video streams, which can be addressed using 3D skeleton data as input for computer vision or machine learning algorithms. Similarly, the 'the problem of online action detection' is a challenge that requires addressing this issue. These datasets and problems are all related to each other through their broader terms.
